properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 2 to 5 millimetres of freezing precipitation is expected. The freezing rain will begin Saturday afternoon over Southwestern Quebec before reaching the Outaouais and Central Quebec overnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T13:04:37-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall of 10 to 25 centimetres is expected this weekend. Hazards: 10 to 25 cm of snow Poor road conditions due to accumulating snow Poor visibility in local blowing snow and heavy snow Timing: Snow will begin Saturday morning and last into Sunday. The heaviest snow is expected Saturday afternoon through Sunday morning. Discussion: A snowstorm appears increasingly likely for eastern Manitoulin Island to North Bay. This corridor is where confidence is highest in the largest snowfall amounts. Strong winds in addition to fresh snow may create local blowing and drifting snow in exposed areas. A Snowfall Warning is being considered as this event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T14:32:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T22:33:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2112270530.2020
Area: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, Temiskaming Shores - Temagami
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of freezing rain and rain is expected this weekend. Freezing rain will be favoured over higher terrain, while rain will be favoured elsewhere. Hazards: 20 to 30 mm of rain 5 to 15 mm of ice accretion over higher terrain Isolated power outages and slippery roads and surfaces in areas of freezing rain Timing: Rain and freezing rain will begin early Saturday morning and taper to drizzle by late Saturday evening. Discussion: Patchy snow flurries or some freezing drizzle tonight will change to steadier rain and freezing rain early Saturday morning. Elevation will be a key feature in this system: areas of higher terrain should see prolonged freezing rain and possibly ice storm conditions, whereas areas of lower terrain should experience mainly rain. A Freezing Rain Warning will likely be needed for higher elevation areas to address this threat. A Rainfall Warning is also being considered for lower elevation areas as this event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T11:54:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T19:55:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3195199940.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A messy mix of 5 to 15 cm of snow and ice pellets, plus a risk of freezing rain, is expected Saturday. Hazards: 5 to 15 cm of snow and ice pellets Poor road conditions due to accumulating snow and possible freezing rain. Timing: Snow will begin Friday overnight and become mixed with ice pellets or freezing rain late in the day Saturday. Precipitation should ease overnight. Discussion: A wintry mix of snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain. At this point, a general range of 5 to 15 cm of snow and ice pellets seems likely with a risk of freezing rain. A Freezing Rain Warning will be considered as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T19:04:54-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow storm this weekend. A low pressure system will bring significant snowfall amounts on Saturday and Sunday. Total amounts will range from 15 to 25 centimetres depending on the area. Snow will begin over Central Quebec Saturday evening before reaching Eastern Quebec overnight. Poor driving conditions are expected. Consider modifying any non-essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets, and a prolonged period of freezing rain is possible this weekend. Hazards: Freezing rain, possibly lasting several hours. 3-8 mm of ice accretion. Local power outages and slippery surfaces. Timing: Precipitation will begin Saturday morning and last into Sunday. Discussion: An approaching system will bring a transition zone of precipitation with it from east of Georgian Bay to Ottawa and eastern Ontario. Along this zone, several hours of freezing rain may be possible, favouring ice build up on untreated surfaces and power lines. Precipitation will likely include a mix of rain, snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain. Snowfall accumulations are generally anticipated to be limited to 5 cm or less. A Freezing Rain Warning will be considered as this event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T20:51:28-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is possible beginning early Sunday morning. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, except near 15 cm over the Highlands. Locations: Victoria County and Inverness County - Mabou and north. Time span: early Sunday morning to Sunday afternoon. Remarks: Snow is expected to move into Cape Breton Sunday morning, become mixed with or change to ice pellets and rain before tapering off Sunday afternoon. There is still uncertainty with the track of this weather system and the total amount of snow and ice pellets. The public is advised to monitor future forecast updates for possible warnings. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lasting blizzard conditions with potentially damaging winds and persistent visibility near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions near the Richardson Mountains. Easterly winds will increase to 70 km/h gusting to 90 tonight and to 90 km/h gusting to 120 on Saturday and will combine with loose snow to reduce visibility to 400 metres or less. This blizzard is expected to last through the weekend. Winds will ease slightly Sunday night but visibility may still be poor in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions will abate early next week. ### Travel is expected to be very difficult or impossible due to near-zero visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T15:25:34-00:00

properties.Summary:

Snow will begin Saturday afternoon over western regions of the province and in the evening over central regions. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected for Tobermory and the northern Bruce Peninsula. Hazards: 10 to 20 cm of snow Heavy wet snow making snow clearing difficult Poor visibility in periods of heavy snow Timing: Steadier snow will begin early Saturday morning and last into Sunday morning. The heaviest snow is expected Saturday afternoon and evening. Discussion: An approaching system will spread precipitation ahead of it on Saturday. The fine line between heavy rain and heavy snow may find itself dividing the Bruce Peninsula for this event. In the northern Bruce Peninsula, snow is expected to be the predominant form of precipitation through Saturday, but it may mix with rain at times through the day. This snow will likely be wet and heavy, making snow clearing difficult. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T19:01:23-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of freezing rain over higher terrain expected Saturday. Hazards: Freezing rain for many hours 5 to 15 mm of ice accretion Utility outages and hazardous road conditions Timing: Freezing rain will begin early Saturday morning and taper to drizzle by late Saturday evening. Discussion: Patchy snow flurries or some freezing drizzle tonight will change to steadier freezing rain early Saturday morning and last into the evening. Harder hit areas like Feversham could experience ice storm conditions with as much as 15 mm of ice accretion, more than enough to create hazardous road conditions and likely enough to cause utility outages. Elevation will be a key feature in this system: areas of higher terrain should see prolonged freezing rain, whereas areas of lower terrain should experience mainly rain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T19:02:32-00:00

Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected Saturday before changing over to rain. Hazards: Freezing rain Ice accretion up to 2 mm Untreated roads and surfaces may become slippery Timing: Freezing rain will begin late Saturday morning and switch to rain by Saturday evening. Discussion: An approaching system will spread precipitation ahead of it Saturday. This precipitation may start as freezing rain for a few hours before switching to rain as temperatures warm. Some ice accretion is possible, and untreated roads and surfaces may become slippery. With the warm up into the evening, any ice accretion from the morning should melt. A Freezing Rain Warning is being considered as this event draws nearer. Note, Environment Canada's criteria for a Freezing Rain Warning is freezing rain lasting 2 or more hours or causing impact. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T19:04:00-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Prolonged snowfall event expected beginning Saturday evening. Total snowfall: 15 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 40 to 60 km/h. Locations: central and northern New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday evening through Sunday night. Remarks: Heavy snow is expected to spread across parts of New Brunswick on Saturday evening, with strong winds and local blowing snow possible. The snow will likely change briefly to freezing rain or ice pellets over south-central parts of the province on Saturday night. Coastal regions along the Fundy shore should remain warm enough for rain with this system. There still remains some uncertainty with the exact track of this system, and the intensity of the snowfall. The rain-snow line may shift slightly and warnings for snow and freezing rain may be required as this system draws nearer. Conditions will improve across the Maritimes on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T17:51:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-12T01:52:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4074518056.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 centimetres are expected in addition to 2 to 4 millimetres of freezing precipitation locally. Snow and blowing snow will begin Saturday afternoon and will last until Sunday morning. The snow may change to freezing rain over some areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

Description: Snowfall of 10 to 15 centimetres expected this weekend. Hazards: 10 to 15 cm of snow Poor road conditions due to accumulating snow Poor visibility in local blowing snow and heavy snow Timing: Snow will begin Saturday morning and last into Sunday. The heaviest snow is expected Saturday afternoon through early evening. Discussion: Uncertainty in the exact track of this system makes forecasting precise snowfall amounts difficult at this time. A Snowfall Warning may be issued as confidence grows over this storm's track. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts of 20 to 35 mm are expected Saturday. Hazards: 20 to 35 mm of rain Timing: Steadier rain will begin early Saturday morning and last into Saturday evening. Discussion: An approaching system will spread precipitation ahead of it on Saturday, bringing 20 to 35 mm of rainfall. The ground, already near saturation and snow covered in many areas, has little ability to absorb further rainfall. This rain will fall as freezing rain in higher elevation areas. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Be prepared for winter conditions at higher elevations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected to develop this evening. Poor visibility in blowing snow will continue until Saturday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T20:00:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-12T04:01:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1765433831.2020
Area: Cambridge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Hazards: 15 to 25 cm of snow Poor visibility in heavy and local blowing snow Poor road conditions due to accumulating and local blowing snow Timing: Snow will begin Saturday morning and last into Sunday. The heaviest snow is expected Saturday afternoon and evening. Discussion: A snowstorm will bring 15 to 25 cm of snow this weekend. Snow will begin Saturday morning, but the heaviest snow is expected in the afternoon and evening hours. Gusty winds will combine with fresh snow to create blowing and drifting snow, particularly in exposed areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T19:01:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-12T03:02:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4073509864.2020
